Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Failure Events Modeling and Analysis for Proactive Management in Highly Dependable Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In large-scale computer systems, component failures are no longer rare events. As the scale of the systems continues to increase, their reliability and service availability become an increasingly critical concern. Recent IT expenditure analyses also show that the worldwide spending in server management and administration has surpassed the cost of new server acquisition. Conventional reactive trouble-shooting measures and conservative check-pointing approaches are often counter-productive or may cause a long time service disruption. The goal of this FEMA project is to develop modeling and analytical methodologies and tools to characterize the systems failure dynamics for proactive failure management in highly dependable systems.

This FEMA project is carried out in three aspects. First is the development of an aggregated spherical covariance model that characterizes the failure dynamics quantitatively. The model centers on a failure signature concept that correlates a group of OS-level performance parameters and operation-level job allocation information to different types of fault events in both space and time domains. Second is an innovative application of statistical learning methods for failure prediction. Different failures types in different system scopes have different failure dynamics and different amount of history data for training; different prediction metrics pose different requirements for prediction granularity. Various supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning algorithms find their applications in different scenarios. Third is the development of system reliability traces for offline evaluation and a methodology for online prediction in production systems. The trace not only contains a log of failure events, but also their corresponding operational contexts that are necessary for attaining high prediction accuracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today's highend systems and virtual machine-based cloud platforms pose a severe productivity problem because their mean times between failures continuously drop as their scale increases. Recent server market analyses also show the world IT spending in server management and administration has surpassed the combined cost of new server purchasing and power and cooling.

This project aims to develop modeling and analytical methodologies and tools to characterize the systems failure dynamics for proactive system management, including virtual machine and service migration, which would enable system administrators to take preventive measures before failures and other system anomalies occur and assist them in rootcause diagnosis to reduce unscheduled downtime.  Significant results include spatial-temporal models for system anomaly detection, differentiaton models of failure remediation, reliability-aware virtual machiche migration mechanisms and policies, and automatic cloud management and performance optimization technqiues based on machine learning and control theories. 

Deliverables that emerge from this project are expected to advance discovery and understanding of the reliability of large scale complex systems, with profound technical, economic, and societal impact. By fusing the failure prediction technology and tools into the systems' autonomic management framework, this research sets to enhance their reliability and productivity to a new level. In addition, this project has an integral educational component. More than 15 students are trained in research and four Ph.D. students are graduated from this project.
